description: HTTP methods, status codes, headers, JSON, and the request-response cycle

cards.front: What is the HTTP request-response cycle?
cards.back:
1. Client sends a REQUEST to a server
2. Server processes it
3. Server sends back a RESPONSE

Client --- GET /posts/1 ---> Server
Client <-- 200 OK + JSON --- Server

Every web page visit and API call follows this cycle.

cards.front: What are the 5 main HTTP methods?
cards.back:
GET    — read data
POST   — create new data
PUT    — replace data entirely
PATCH  — update part of data
DELETE — remove data

GET /users       — list all users
POST /users      — create a user
GET /users/42    — get user 42
DELETE /users/42 — delete user 42

cards.front: What do HTTP status code ranges mean?
cards.back:
2xx — Success (200 OK, 201 Created, 204 No Content)
3xx — Redirect (301 Moved, 304 Not Modified)
4xx — Client error / your fault (400 Bad Request, 401 Unauthorized, 404 Not Found)
5xx — Server error / their fault (500 Internal Error, 503 Unavailable)

First digit tells you the category.

cards.front: What is JSON and why is it used in APIs?
cards.back:
JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) — the standard data format for APIs.

{"name": "Alice", "age": 30, "hobbies": ["reading"]}

In Python:
import json
json.dumps(data)  # dict -> JSON string
json.loads(text)  # JSON string -> dict
response.json()   # parse HTTP response body

Key-value metadata attached to requests and responses.

Common request headers:
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer <token>
Accept: application/json

Common response headers:
Content-Type: application/json
Cache-Control: max-age=3600

Headers configure how the request/response is processed.

cards.front: How do you make HTTP requests in Python?
cards.back:
import requests

# GET
response = requests.get("https://api.example.com/users")
data = response.json()

# POST
response = requests.post(url, json={"name": "Alice"})

# Check status
response.status_code       # 200
response.raise_for_status() # raises on 4xx/5xx

cards.front: What is the difference between query parameters and request body?
cards.back:
Query parameters — in the URL, for filtering/searching:
GET /users?age=30&city=Portland

Request body — in the message, for sending data:
POST /users
Body: {"name": "Alice", "age": 30}

GET uses query params. POST/PUT use the body.
Query params are visible in the URL. Body is not.

cards.front: Why should you always use timeout when making HTTP requests?
cards.back:
Without timeout, your program can hang forever if the server does not respond.

# BAD — can hang forever:
requests.get(url)

# GOOD — fails after 10 seconds:
requests.get(url, timeout=10)

Always set a timeout. Handle timeouts with try/except.
